section.title: Reconfiguring the Disk Model of a Deployed VSA
section.para: Reconfiguring VSA verbs to add extra disks to the already deployed VSA.

With the development of a new automation playbook, you can add new disks to the already deployed VSA. This allows you to gradually increase the storage capacity of a cluster, i.e. at the time of initial deployment. For example, you can start with a deployment of VSA with a single disk, create a cluster and user it for cloud use cases. Later, you can add new disks to VSA nodes and run the playbook. This way all the VSA nodes will see the extra disk and hence forms a cluster of higher capacity. It is recommended to use playbook to extend disk model instead of using CMC to add a new set of disks. Directly going to CMC will lead in discrepancy in Helion OpenStack VSA disks model vs. disk sets presented to the VSA system.

section.title: Prerequisite
section.para: Before adding a disk to a deployed VSA, ensure the following:

listitem.para: Disks are already mounted to each VSA node.
Only SSD are added to tier 0 (for AO), no check to validate it.
Capacity of each added disk is more than 5 GB.
Add a same number of disks to the VSA nodes of a respective cluster.

section.title: Procedure to Reconfigure the Existing VSA Disk
section.para: You can reconfigure the existing VSA disk for a single or multiple cluster(s).

para.emphasis: Procedure to reconfigure the existing VSA disk for a single cluster

section.para: To reconfigure the existing VSA disk for a single cluster, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Login to lifecycle manager.
Edit ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/disks_vsa.yml file and add a single disk.

In the following example, three disks are added. Two disks /dev/sdd and /dev/sde are added for data disks and one disk /dev/sdf for adaptive optimization. With the addition of the new disks, the disk model should reflect as follows.
listitem.screen: # Disks to be used by VSA # Additional disks can be added if available device-groups: - name: vsa-data consumer: name: vsa usage: data devices: - name: /dev/sdd - name: /dev/sde - name: vsa-cache consumer: name: vsa usage: adaptive-optimization devices: - name: /dev/sdf

para.emphasis: Procedure to Reconfigure the Existing VSA Disk for multiple cluster

section.para: If you have multiple cluster and you want to expand the disk sets of only one cluster, make sure to verify the following points:

listitem.para: Check the usage of disk model. If it is using the same disk model then create a new disk model.
If you want to configure a disk model of a one cluster, edit the respective disk model.

section.para: In the following example, two clusters are defined for two disk models: VSA-DISKS and VSA-DISKS-2. dev/sdd and dev/sde disks are added only to the second cluster.
section.screen: disk-models: - name: VSA-DISKS # Disks to be used by VSA # Additional disks can be added if available device-groups: - name: vsa-data consumer: name: vsa usage: data devices: - name: /dev/sdc - name: vsa-cache consumer: name: vsa usage: adaptive-optimization devices: - name: /dev/sdb - name: VSA-DISKS-2 # Disks to be used by VSA # Additional disks can be added if availiable device-groups: - name: vsa-data consumer: name: vsa usage: data devices: - name: /dev/sdc - name: /dev/sdd - name: vsa-cache consumer: name: vsa usage: adaptive-optimization devices: - name: /dev/sdb - name: /dev/sde

para.emphasis: Commit the change and run the playbooks

listitem.para: Commit the changes to the local git repo.
listitem.screen: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -a -m "<commit message>"

listitem.para: Run the configuration processor.
Update your deployment directory.
Run disk configuration playbook to add disk(s) to VSA:
This playbook verifies the physical existence of the disk and checks that the total disks count does not exceed the limit, i.e., 7.

section.title: Centralized Management Console (CMC)
section.para: Perform the following steps to add disk(s):

listitem.para: Launch the CMC utility.
Select the system in the Available Systems pool and click &plusicon; to expand the mg-vsa (VSA node) in which you have added the extra disk in the input model.
Click &plusicon; cluster-vsa to expand.
Click &plusicon; Storage Systems and VSA-VM-vsa1 to expand and select Storage.

On the Disk Setup tab, place the cursor in the status Uninitializing in the status column, right click on the status and then select Add Disk to RAID and Set Tiers. The disk(s) which is added in the input model appears in the Disk Setup tab.
Select appropriate disk(s) to RAID and set the desired tier and click OK
A pop-up box appears. Click Yes to add a disk to RAID.
A warning message is displayed in the screen. Click Yes to proceed.
Click OK to proceed further.
The status that appears in the status column will change from Uninitializing to Active. Now you can see the additional disks added to VSA in an active status.
Repeat the steps from 2-9 for all the VSA system to which you want to add the disks.

warning.para: Do not add/delete a new volume until the status of a newly added disk does not change to Active state. Do not perform any volume lifecycle operations until the newly added disk gets into the active state.
